Title: Tracking Coronavirus: Map, Data and Timeline
Content: This website has daily reports on the number of coronavirus cases across the world split up by geographical region and by country.

This webpage provides an overview of the number of COVID-19 cases in the U.S., overall and by state. The webpage shows the national trend in COVID-19 cases by their report date and by the estimated date of illness onset.

Source name: European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control
Title: Situation Update Worldwide
Content: This website provides case counts of COVID-19 worldwide, by country.

This is John Hopkins University's Github repository, which includes a list of their data sources in addition to datasets with case counts including WHO daily case reports and their own compilation of case counts based on individual country reports.

This website includes a dashboard with information on COVID-19 cases and testing at the county level in the U.S. and province level in Canada. It also includes information on school closures and other impacts COVID-19 has had on events around the world. It includes a link to request data, and asks users not to scrape their website.

Title: Global Pandemic Real-Time Report
Content: This website has graphs and tables showing counts of confirmed cases, daily new cases, and deaths, by continent and country. The graphs and tables are based on data compiled from the WHO, CDC, and reliable media sources (such as CNN and the BBC).

Title: COVID-19 Coronavirus Pandemic
Content: This is a real-time count of COVID-19 cases worldwide, by country.
This website includes a real-time tally of COVID-19 cases around the world presented in a table.

Title: University of Southern California’s Student-Compiled COVID-19-TweetIDs
Content: This repository contains raw Twitter data on topics related to COVID-19 from January 28, 2020. Its data is in multiple languages and spans the globe.

This link directs to data from Washington state's Rapid Health Information NetwOrk (RHINO) program, which collects real-time, population-based healthcare visit data from hospitals and clinics across the state. It is used to identify, investigate, and design data-driven, rapid responses to emerging public health threats. These data can provide insights into chronic disease burden, environmental threats, communicable disease outbreaks, and injury trends. Data is forwarded to the National Syndromic Surveillance Program (NSSP) for national surveillance. You need to request data to access it.
This website contains information on COVID-19-induced policies by state in tabular format.

This ArcGIS solution includes a collection of maps and apps intended for use by public health agencies to understand the impact of COVID-19. The solution includes applications to track cases, policy changes, and testing sites.

Title: Novel Coronavirus (Covid-19)
Content: This is a link to compiled data collected from WHO, CDC, various local agencies and news organizations around the world related to counts of COVID-19 cases.

Title: National Institute of Health, National Libraries of Medicine
Content: This is a curated literature hub that tracks up-to-date scientific information about the 2019 novel coronavirus published in PubMed. The website links to articles organized by topic (for example, treatment, diagnosis, or number of cases).

Title: New York Times COVID-19 GitHub Repository
Content: This is a repository of real-time county level cases.

Category: Policy and legislative actions to curb transmission
Title: Google Doc: COVID-19 US State Policy Database
Content: This is a living document tracking states’ policy changes.

Title: Corona Data Scraper
Content: Corona Data Scraper pulls COVID-19 case data from verified sources, finds the corresponding GeoJSON features, and adds population data.

Title: Postman COVID-19 API Resource Center
Content: Compilations of APIs and documentation to scrape COVID-19 data.

Category: Policy and legislative actions to curb transmission
Title: McDermottPlus COVID-19 Guidance Tracker
Content: This living document is a summary of policy measures taken by federal agencies and states related to COVID-19.

Title: American Community Survey
Content: The ACS is an ongoing survey of more than 3.5 million households across the country that provides vital information on a yearly basis about the United States and its people. The resulting data set provides extremely detailed demographic information, aggregated at various geographic levels, to help determine how more than $675 billion in federal and state funding are distributed each year. This data set is freely available on Google Cloud. (After clicking “View Dataset,” first-time users need to create a project in Google Cloud to access the data).

Title: Births Data Summary
Content: This data set contains natality data based on CDC-collected statistics for live births occurring within the United States to U.S. residents. The data capture a range of maternal demographic information, such as state, county of residence, age, race, ethnicity, country of origin, marital status, and education. It also includes health and medical data on these mothers, such as prior birth history; prenatal care visits; enrollment in the Special Supplemental Nutrition Program for Women, Infants, and Children; tobacco use; method of delivery; method of payment; and congenital anomalies and other morbidity data.

Source name: U.S. Department of Health & Human Services
Title: Center for Medicare and Medicaid Services - Dual Enrollment
Content: This public data set was created by CMS and summarizes counts of enrollees who are dually eligible for both the Medicare and Medicaid programs, including those in Medicare Savings Programs.

Title: GDP and Income by County
Content: This public data set provides a county-level view of income, wages, proprietors’ income, dividends, interest, rents, and government benefits, including a number of federal- and state-level subsidies.

Title: Global Health
Content: This data set combines key health statistics from a variety of sources (including the World Bank data catalog, Johns Hopkins University Github data, official sources, international organizations, World Bank Group regional teams, and other authoritative sources) to provide a look at global health and population trends with respect to nutrition, reproductive health, education, immunization, and diseases from more than 200 countries. This data set is freely available on Google Cloud. (After clicking “View Dataset,” first-time users need to create a project in Google Cloud to access the data).

Source name: U.S. Department of Health & Human Services
Title: Health Professional Shortage Areas
Content: This data set contains federally designated areas or populations with a shortage of health care workers. The Health Resource Service Administration’s Bureau of Health Workforce developed criteria to designate whether or not an area or population is a Health Professional Shortage Area, Medically Underserved Area, or Medically Underserved Population. The data set is freely available on Google Cloud. (After clicking “View Dataset,” first-time users need to create a project in Google Cloud to access the data).

Source name: U.S. Department of Health & Human Services
Title: Hospital General Information
Content: This data table includes all hospitals that have been registered with Medicare. This list includes addresses, phone numbers, hospital types, and quality of care information. Quality of care data are available for more than 4,000 Medicare-certified hospitals across the country, including more than 130 Veterans Affairs medical centers. You can use these data to find hospitals and compare the quality of their care. This data set is freely available on Google Cloud. (After clicking “View Dataset,” first-time users need to create a project in Google Cloud to access the data).

Title: International Census Data
Content: The U.S. Census Bureau’s international data set provides estimates of country populations since 1950 and projections through 2050. Specifically, the data set includes midyear population figures, broken down by age and gender assignment at birth. In addition, time-series data are provided for fertility rates, birth rates, death rates, and migration rates. This data set is freely available on Google Cloud. (After clicking “View Dataset,” first-time users need to create a project in Google Cloud to access the data).

Source name: U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development
Title: Low Income Housing Tax Credit Program
Content: The LIHTC program gives state and local agencies the equivalent of nearly $8 billion in annual budget authority to issue tax credits for the acquisition, rehabilitation, or new construction of rental housing targeted to lower-income households. The LIHTC database, created by HUD and available to the public since 1997, contains information on more than 47,000 projects and 3 million housing units placed in service between 1987 and 2017. It is the only complete national source of information on the size, unit mix, and location of individual projects.

Title: OpenStreetMap Public Dataset
Data quality notes: OSM is a collaborative project, initiated in 2004, to create a free editable map of the world. Based on the model used by Wikipedia, more than two million registered users can add data by manual survey, GPS devices, aerial photography, and other free sources. This data set is freely available on Google Cloud. (After clicking “View Dataset,” first-time users need to create a project in Google Cloud to access the data).

Source name: U.S Departmet of Housing and Urban Development
Title: Point-in-Time Homelessness Count
Content: This database represents the most comprehensive national-level assessment of homelessness in America and is based on data reported in the Annual Homeless Assessment Report to Congress. The data include point-in-time counts of homeless individuals; housing inventory counts conducted annually; and estimates of chronically homeless persons, homeless veterans, and homeless children and youth. This data set is freely available on Google Cloud. (After clicking “View Dataset,” first-time users need to create a project in Google Cloud to access the data).

Title: SNAP Enrollment
Content: This public data set published by USDA summarizes the total number of enrollees in SNAP by region. SNAP provides nutrition benefits to supplement the food budget of families and persons meeting eligibility criteria related to monthly income.

Title: U.S. Census Data
Content: The U.S. census count (also known as the Decennial Census of Population and Housing) is a count of every U.S. resident. The census occurs every 10 years and is conducted by the U.S. Census Bureau. Census data are publicly available through the census website, but much of the data are available in summarized data and graphs. The raw data are often difficult to obtain, are typically divided by region, and must be processed and combined to provide information about the nation as a whole. This data set is freely available on Google Cloud. (After clicking “View Dataset,” first-time users need to create a project in Google Cloud to access the data).
